sn45.160:4.1: “Mendicants, suppose that, although the Ganges river slants, slopes, and inclines to the east,
sn45.160:4.2: a large crowd were to come along with a spade and basket, saying:
sn45.160:4.3: ‘We’ll make this Ganges river slant, slope, and incline to the west!’
sn45.160:4.4: What do you think, mendicants? Would they succeed?”
sn45.160:4.7: The Ganges river slants, slopes, and inclines to the east.
sn45.160:4.8: It’s not easy to make it slant, slope, and incline to the west.
sn45.160:4.9: That large crowd will eventually get weary and frustrated.”
sn45.160:4.10: “In the same way, while a mendicant develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path, if rulers or their ministers, friends or colleagues, relatives or family should invite them to accept wealth, saying:
sn45.160:4.11: ‘Please, mister, why let these ocher robes torment you? Why follow the practice of shaving your head and carrying an alms bowl? Come, return to a lesser life, enjoy wealth, and make merit!’
sn45.160:4.13: It’s simply impossible for a mendicant who develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path to abandon the training and return to a lesser life.
sn45.160:4.16: Because for a long time that mendicant’s mind has slanted, sloped, and inclined to seclusion. So it’s impossible for them to return to a lesser life.
sn45.160:4.18: And how does a mendicant develop and cultivate the noble eightfold path?
sn45.160:4.19: It’s when a mendicant develops right view, right motivation, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness,
sn45.160:4.20: and right samādhi, which relies on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripens as letting go.
sn45.160:4.21: That’s how a mendicant develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path.”
